messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Packaging is the paper or plastic around food.

For the last ten years, people said big supermarkets did bad things. They threw away a lot of food. They did not pay enough money to their suppliers. They also used too much plastic for their packaging. This was bad for our world.

But now, supermarkets are starting to listen. People are angry about all the plastic rubbish. So, some of the biggest supermarkets in the UK made a promise. They will change their packaging. And they will use less plastic.

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6728 is significantly below the required 0.75 threshold. This indicates a critical loss of the original text's core message.

- Primary Failure: The original text describes specific, serious concepts like 'unethical acts', 'accusations', and 'consumer backlash'. Your version simplifies these to 'bad things' and 'people are angry'. This oversimplification removes the essential meaning of formal public criticism and organized opposition.
- Secondary Failure: The BERTScore of 0.898 is just below the 0.90 minimum. This is a direct result of replacing key lexical items like 'unethical acts' and 'backlash' with generic phrases, reducing fidelity to the source.
- The concept of a formal 'pact' was reduced to a simple 'promise', which is a weaker and less precise term in this context.

Suggestion: The text must be rewritten to better capture the original meaning while maintaining A2 simplicity. Restore the concept of public criticism. Instead of 'did bad things', use a phrase like 'were not fair' or 'did wrong things'. To address 'backlash', use a phrase like 'customers were very unhappy and complained'. The text must convey not just anger, but active opposition.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Packaging is the paper or plastic around food.

For the last ten years, people said big supermarkets were not fair. They threw away a lot of food. They did not pay enough money to their suppliers. They also used too much plastic for their packaging. This was bad for our world.

But now, supermarkets are starting to listen. Customers were very unhappy and complained about the plastic rubbish. So, some of the biggest supermarkets in the UK made an agreement. They will change their packaging. And they will use less plastic.

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6566 is significantly below the required 0.75 threshold. This indicates a failure to preserve the core message of the original text.

- The original text describes 'unethical acts' and 'consumer backlash'. Your version weakens this to 'not fair' and 'unhappy'. This loses the critical meaning of public anger forcing a change in corporate behavior.
- The BERTScore of 0.8973 is also below the 0.90 minimum, confirming a loss of key phrasing from the original source.
- Vocabulary Violation: The word 'agreement' is B1 level. This is too advanced for an A2 text.

Suggestion: Rephrase to restore the concept of public anger and pressure. Replace the B1 word 'agreement' with the A2 phrase 'made a promise'. The text must more accurately reflect the cause-and-effect relationship described in the original.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Packaging is the paper or plastic around food.

For the last ten years, people said big supermarkets did bad things. They threw away a lot of food. They did not pay enough money to their suppliers. They also used too much plastic for their packaging. This was bad for our world.

But now, supermarkets are starting to listen. Customers were very angry about the plastic rubbish. Because of this, some of the biggest supermarkets in the UK made a promise. They will change their packaging. And they will use less plastic.

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.683 is significantly below the required 0.75 threshold. This indicates a critical loss of the original text's core message.

- Primary Meaning Deviation: The original text describes a serious conflict using terms like 'unethical acts', 'consumer backlash', and a formal 'pact'. Your version reduces this to 'did bad things', 'customers were very angry', and 'made a promise'. This oversimplification loses the gravity and the formal nature of the situation.

- Fidelity Failure: The BERTScore of 0.8976 is below the minimum requirement of 0.90. This is a direct result of replacing key factual terms from the original text, such as 'major supermarket chains' and 'consumer backlash', with less precise A2 equivalents.

- Consequence: The text no longer accurately reflects the source material's description of a public and professional response to accusations of unethical behavior.

Suggestion: The text must be rewritten to better capture the original meaning. Restore the concept of a formal agreement. Change 'made a promise' to 'agreed to a new plan'. Change 'did bad things' to a more specific phrase like 'did not do the right thing for suppliers or the world'.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Packaging is the paper or plastic around food.

For the last ten years, people said big supermarkets did not do the right thing. They threw away a lot of food. They did not pay enough money to their suppliers. They also used too much plastic for their packaging. This was bad for our world.

But now, supermarkets are starting to listen. Customers were very angry about the plastic rubbish. Because of this, some of the biggest supermarkets in the UK agreed to a new plan. They will change their packaging. And they will use less plastic.

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6605 is significantly below the required 0.75 threshold. This indicates a critical loss of the original text's core message. The BERTScore of 0.8965 is also below the 0.90 minimum, showing a loss of key vocabulary.

- The primary failure is the dilution of meaning. The original text's concepts of 'accusations,' 'unethical acts,' and 'consumer backlash' are central. Your version's 'people said,' 'did not do the right thing,' and 'customers were very angry' are too simple and lose the sense of formal public criticism and pressure.
- The phrase 'come under fire' implies a sustained period of intense criticism. 'People said' does not carry this meaning and is a factual simplification.
- The term 'pact' in the original implies a formal, binding agreement. Your replacement, 'plan,' is weaker and less specific, which contributed to the low metric scores.
- While the text correctly classifies as A2, its oversimplification has damaged the integrity of the original message, leading to the metric failures.

Suggestion: Rephrase to restore the lost meaning. The concept of public criticism must be clearer. Instead of 'people said,' use 'Many people said that the supermarkets were doing bad things.' To restore the concept of a formal agreement, change 'agreed to a new plan' to 'promised to make changes.'

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Packaging is the paper or plastic around food.
For the last ten years, many people said that the supermarkets were doing bad things. They threw away a lot of food. They did not pay enough money to their suppliers. They also used too much plastic for their packaging. This was bad for our world.

But now, supermarkets are starting to listen. Customers were very angry about the plastic rubbish. Because of this, some of the biggest supermarkets in the UK promised to make changes. They will change their packaging. And they will use less plastic.

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6679 is significantly below the required 0.75 threshold. This indicates a failure to preserve the core message of the original text. The original text describes formal 'accusations', 'unethical acts', and 'consumer backlash', which your version simplifies to 'doing bad things' and 'customers were very angry'. This simplification loses the critical concepts of public criticism and pressure. Additionally, the BERTScore of 0.899 is below the required 0.90, indicating a loss of key lexical items like 'come under fire' and 'signed up to a pact'.

- Deviation 1: MeaningBERT score is 0.6679. This is an instant failure. The meaning is too diluted.
- Deviation 2: BERTScore is 0.899. This is an instant failure. Key vocabulary from the original was lost.
- Deviation 3: The phrase 'signed up to a pact' implies a formal, binding agreement. Your version, 'promised to make changes', is weaker and does not carry the same weight, contributing to the meaning loss.

Suggestion: Rephrase to restore the lost meaning without increasing complexity. Change 'many people said that the supermarkets were doing bad things' to 'many people were unhappy with the big supermarkets'. Change 'promised to make changes' to 'agreed to a plan to make changes'. This restores the concepts of public pressure and formal agreement.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Packaging is the paper or plastic around food.
For the last ten years, many people were unhappy with the big supermarkets. They threw away a lot of food. They did not pay enough money to their suppliers. They also used too much plastic for their packaging. This was bad for our world.

But now, supermarkets are starting to listen. Customers were very angry about the plastic rubbish. Because of this, some of the biggest supermarkets in the UK agreed to a plan to make changes. They will change their packaging. And they will use less plastic.

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.7096 is below the required threshold of 0.75. This is a critical failure to preserve the core message of the original text.

- The original text states supermarkets signed a 'pact promising to transform packaging'. Your version, 'agreed to a plan to make changes', is a significant downgrade in meaning. It loses the critical concept of a formal, binding promise and replaces it with a weak, non-committal plan.
- The original's 'consumer backlash' implies organized, public pressure. Your version, 'Customers were very angry', simplifies this to a general emotion, losing the nuance of a targeted reaction that forced change.
- While the BERTScore of 0.9001 is technically a pass, the failure on the MeaningBERT metric indicates that while you used similar words, the overall message was distorted.

Suggestion: The text must be rewritten to restore the lost meaning. The concept of a 'pact' or 'strong promise' must be included. Change 'agreed to a plan' to 'made a strong promise to change'.
